title: 108_hr2539
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Violence Against Children Act of 2003". Congress finds that children under 18 account for a significant portion of crime victims, especially in sex crimes and kidnappings. Adolescents aged 12-17 are more likely to be victims of violent crime than adults. Many crimes against children go unreported, leading to long-lasting negative effects such as delayed development and substance abuse. Lack of resources hinders local agencies from adequately protecting children and families in need. Failure to pay child support is considered a form of neglect. Failure to pay child support is a form of neglect, as it can lead to children living in poverty and lacking education, healthcare, and housing. TITLE I--ENHANCED FEDERAL ROLE IN CRIMES AGAINST CHILDREN

SEC. 101. ENHANCED PENALTIES. Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section on violence against children. It specifies penalties for anyone who willfully injures a person under 18 years of age, including imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines. Harsher penalties apply if the offense results in death, involves kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder. The circumstances include the conduct occurring during travel of the defendant or victim. The new section in Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, addresses violence against children. It outlines penalties for causing harm to individuals under 18 years old, with harsher consequences for offenses resulting in death, kidnapping, sexual abuse, or attempted murder. The conduct must occur during travel across state lines or using interstate commerce, and the use of certain weapons can lead to additional penalties. The United States Sentencing Commission will enhance penalties for federal crimes against children under 18. The Comptroller General will review state laws on crimes against children and report findings to Congress. Additionally, there will be enhanced assistance for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials. Enhanced assistance for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials will be provided by the Attorney General upon request from a State, Indian tribal government, or unit of local government. Priority will be given to crimes of violence, felonies against individuals under 18, crimes committed across multiple states, and rural jurisdictions facing financial challenges in investigating or prosecuting crimes. Federal assistance will be provided to state and local law enforcement agencies for criminal investigations and prosecutions. Priority will be given to crimes of violence, felonies against individuals under 18, crimes committed across multiple states, and rural jurisdictions facing financial challenges. The Attorney General will award grants to assist States, Indian tribal governments, and local government units in enhancing law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children. The grants will provide personnel, training, technical assistance, and equipment to improve apprehension, prosecution, and adjudication of offenders. Specific purposes include training law enforcement officers, prosecutors, judges, and court personnel, developing specialized units targeting crimes against children, implementing effective policies and services for preventing and responding to such crimes, and enhancing data collection efforts. The grants aim to prevent, identify, and respond to crimes against children by developing data collection systems, enhancing collaboration between law enforcement and child services agencies, and addressing the needs of Indian tribes. Applicants must submit an application to the Attorney General to receive the grant. Applicants for the grant must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information, describe the grant's purposes, intended use of funds, and expected results. They must also demonstrate consultation with victim services programs and certify the proper use of any Federal funds received. Authorization of Appropriations.-- $25,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually from 2004 to 2008 to supplement non-Federal funds for victim services programs and ensure compliance with specified sections. SEC. 202. EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND VICTIMS' ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants are used for seminars, hotlines, training programs, informational materials, intervention services, awareness efforts, emergency medical treatment, and counseling for victims and their families. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children, including emergency medical treatment, counseling, and increasing mental health professionals specializing in victims' mental health. States, tribal governments, local governments, or organizations must submit applications describing the grant's purposes and intended use. The grant application must detail the purposes, intended use of funds, and expected results. Consultation with victim services programs is required for government entities, while nongovernmental organizations must demonstrate relevant experience. The organization must have experience in providing education, prevention, or intervention services for crimes against children or victims of such crimes. They must certify that federal funds will supplement, not replace, non-federal funds for these activities. Waivers may be granted in exceptional circumstances for nongovernmental organizations. The nongovernmental organization must operate activities funded under this section in compliance with section 303. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008 to carry out these activities. TITLE III--NATIONWIDE PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. NATIONWIDE AMBER ALERT.

Each State receiving grants must establish a statewide AMBER Alert network for child abduction cases within 3 years.

SEC. 302. IMPROVED STATISTICAL GATHERING.

States must use or develop protocols to use the National Incident-Based Reporting System.

SEC. 303. NATIONAL SAFE HAVEN. Each State receiving grants must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn baby with a hospital employee anonymously without penalty, collect family medical history, search missing person databases, and publicize the State's Safe Haven law. Exceptions apply if the baby shows signs of abuse. Parents can leave a newborn baby anonymously without penalty if the baby shows signs of abuse. Improved Child Protection Services Programs. States receiving funding for child welfare services must submit a report on their programs within 180 days. The General Accounting Office will also report to Congress on state practices, including record-keeping and well-being verification for children in care. The report will assess the effectiveness of the review system by the Secretary of Health and Human Services in reforming child welfare systems. The review system by the Secretary of Health and Human Services is helping States reform their child welfare system. States are implementing best practices, and Congress is considering legislative changes based on recommendations. TITLE IV--CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT

SENSE OF THE SENATE ON TAX TREATMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT: Congress should pass legislation to extend Federal tax treatment on bad debt to nonpayment of child support by allowing deductions for unpaid child support and requiring unpaid amounts to be added to income for tax purposes.
